content: The Act may be cited as the "U.S. Employee, Family Unity, and Legalization Act." References to the Immigration and Nationality Act are considered to be made to a section of that Act. The Act also addresses the change of entry date into the United States for certain aliens seeking permanent residence. Section 249 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change the entry date into the United States for certain aliens seeking permanent residence. The amendment updates the dates from January 1, 1972 to January 1, 1998, and later to January 1, 1999 and January 1, 2000. Section 249 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is further amended to update entry dates for aliens seeking permanent residence, changing dates from January 1, 2000 to January 1, 2003 in subsequent years. Subsections are also redesignated as paragraphs. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update entry dates for aliens seeking permanent residence. Subsections are redesignated as paragraphs, and new subsections are added regarding violations incidental to undocumented status. These violations shall not affect immigration benefits or status applications under the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update entry dates for aliens seeking permanent residence. Violations incidental to undocumented status shall not affect immigration benefits or status applications under the Act. Confidentiality of information provided in applications must be maintained by the Department of Justice. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update entry dates for aliens seeking permanent residence. Violations incidental to undocumented status shall not affect immigration benefits or status applications under the Act. Anyone who misuses information in applications or makes false statements in adjustment of status applications may face fines or imprisonment. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update entry dates for aliens seeking permanent residence. Violations incidental to undocumented status shall not affect immigration benefits or status applications under the Act. Anyone who misuses information in applications or makes false statements in adjustment of status applications may face fines or imprisonment, as per the U.S. Employee, Family Unity, and Legalization Act. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF RETROACTIVE APPLICATION OF CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update entry dates for aliens seeking permanent residence. Violations incidental to undocumented status shall not affect immigration benefits or status applications under the Act. An alien who committed an offense before April 1, 1997, will have the law in effect at the time of the offense apply to any relief application. Periods of residency in the U.S. will be credited for eligibility for relief, regardless of when they occurred. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update entry dates for aliens seeking permanent residence. Violations incidental to undocumented status shall not affect immigration benefits or status applications under the Act. An alien is not deportable or removable for committing an offense that was not a ground of deportability at the time of the offense. Additionally, an alien is not inadmissible for committing an offense that was not a ground of inadmissibility at the time of the offense. The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, and its amendments, only apply to individuals seeking admission or becoming removable on or after April 1, 1997. The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, specifically Title IV and its amendments, apply only to individuals seeking admission or becoming removable on or after April 24, 1996. Additionally, the repeal of Section 241(a)(5) (8 U.S.C. 1231(a)(5)) applies to all pending proceedings and cases brought on or after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Restoration of proportionality to grounds of removal. The amendment defines crimes involving moral turpitude and aggravated felonies for deportation purposes. Crimes of moral turpitude committed within five years of admission leading to over one year of confinement make an alien deportable. Aggravated felonies now include offenses leading to over five years of confinement. The amendment expands the definition of crimes involving moral turpitude and aggravated felonies for deportation purposes. It includes offenses related to alien smuggling for commercial advantage, changes the term "child" to "son or daughter" in certain cases, increases the minimum sentence for certain offenses from 2 to 5 years, and specifies that a crime is not considered an aggravated felony if the conviction is a misdemeanor or the sentence is less than one year. These amendments apply to convictions before or after the enactment of the Act. The Act expands the definition of crimes for deportation purposes, including offenses related to alien smuggling. It clarifies that certain convictions are not considered aggravated felonies if the sentence is less than one year. The definition of "conviction" is amended to exclude expunged or dismissed records. The U.S.C. 1101(a)(48)(B) is amended to include the period of incarceration ordered by a court of law. Conforming amendments are made to sections 212(a)(6)(E) and 237(a)(1)(E) regarding offenses related to alien smuggling. The U.S.C. 1101(a)(48)(B) is amended to remove "commercial advantage'' after "knowingly'' and redesignate a clause. SEC. 5 eliminates the prohibition on admitting aliens unlawfully present in the U.S. by amending Section 212(a)(9) and Section 248. SEC. 6 introduces a visa for certain spouses and children of citizens and permanent residents waiting for visa numbers. Section 101(a)(15)(V) is amended to allow certain aliens to enter the US for family reunification purposes, excluding those coming for study or work. Section 101(a)(15)(V) is amended to allow aliens to enter the US for family unity with permanent residents, awaiting immigrant visa availability. Amendments are made to Section 214 to redesignate subsections (o) and (p) for conformity. Amendments are made to subsection (p) to strike certain terms and redesignate paragraphs for conformity. Establishment of a national task force on immigrant exploitation and trafficking, consisting of Federal and State law enforcement officers appointed by the Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of State. The task force, chaired by the Secretary of Labor, aims to create a coordinated national and State policy to end exploitation and trafficking of immigrants, recommending coordinated law enforcement efforts for the elimination of employment abuses against immigrant workers.
